issue.title: bisync: beta time improvements

milestone.title: Help Wanted
milestone.description:
Enhancements which might be useful, but currently aren't planned.

Any help doing these much appreciated.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
### Intro

The bisync pull request #5164 appeared too large to fulfil in a single rclone release.

Plan is to merge it right after the rclone v1.57 release. The command will be available in the beta builds for a limited circle of beta testers until official release with rclone v1.58.
During the beta period we can merge a number of postponed items, **in particular breaking changes**.

This ticket will keep track of the most beta time changes. Large and critical changes will be split into separate tickets.
High priority items reflect changes breaking user experience and must be completed before 1.58. Medium priority items are required but not guaranteed by 1.58. Optional and low priority items will be implemented on best effort basis. Optional items don't even have dedicated tickets yet.

### High priority

- [ ] Track critical flags in saved sessions - #5678
- [ ] Support imprecise or absent modtimes - #5679
- [ ] Use hashsums, honor `--checksum` - #5683

### Medium priority

- [ ] Check file sizes - #5684
- [ ] Respect `--backup-dir` - #5685
- [ ] Align `--max-delete` semantics - #5680
- [ ] Optimize resync - #5681
- [ ] Track renames - #5690

### Low priority

- [ ] Handle deletion conflicts - #5691
- [ ] Honor `--interactive` and `--auto-confirm`
- [ ] Recover after transient failures - #5676
- [ ] Use **trie** for listings to reduce footprint - #5686
- [ ] Maintain session history - #5692
- [ ] Handle Google Docs better - #5696

### Optional items

- [ ] Parallelize move/rename operations
- [ ] Honor special `.rcignore` files
- [ ] Revisit progress display for bisync
- [ ] Handle case-insensitive filenames. Respect `--ignore-case` and `--ignore-case-sync` ([rcsync#54](https://github.com/cjnaz/rclonesync-V2/issues/54), [#4854](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/4854))
- [ ] Synchronize empty dirs if supported by backend ([rcsync#63](https://github.com/cjnaz/rclonesync-V2/issues/63))
- [ ] Fix tests for Google Photos ([rcsync#53](https://github.com/cjnaz/rclonesync-V2/issues/53), [G.Photos issues](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22Remote%3A+Google+Photos%22))
- [ ] Enable CI tests with OwnCloud (according to @cjnaz it's stable)
- [ ] Test should handle Dropbox "touch quirks" in a generic way

#### How to use GitHub

* Please use the üëç [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to show that you are affected by the same issue.
* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.

body:
Related to this ticket (and also #5676), `--check-sync` should also support comparing `modtime` (and eventually, when [`checksum`](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/5683) and [`size`](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/5684) are supported, it should use the same sync key used for the bisync run.)

Currently, `--check-sync` only compares filenames, not `modtime`, `size`, or `hash`. It can detect whether a file from one Path is missing on the other, but not whether both Paths have different versions of a file. This can cause issues such as [this one](https://forum.rclone.org/t/bisync-missed-syncing-changed-file-no-error-no-warning/41174/2).

Alternatively, perhaps this would be better handled by outsourcing it to the more robust [`rclone check`](https://tip.rclone.org/bisync/#concurrent-modifications), rather than attempting to duplicate the same functionality in `--check-sync`.

Here's where the trouble is:

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/94a320f23cd9e6ad27a03a2ac3c833f8871129f8/cmd/bisync/operations.go#L474-L479

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/94a320f23cd9e6ad27a03a2ac3c833f8871129f8/cmd/bisync/listing.go#L53-L58

issue.title: bisync: handle unicode normalization consistently

milestone.title: Soon
milestone.description: Issues which are a good idea but haven't been assigned a specific release yet.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Bisync sometimes normalizes NFD to NFC and sometimes does not, causing errors in some scenarios (particularly for users of macOS). See https://forum.rclone.org/t/bisync-question/41434/12

Here is a bare-minimum case to reproduce:
```
% rclone touch NFD/oÃà 
% rclone touch NFC/√∂
% rclone bisync NFD NFC --resync
2023/09/02 18:23:08 NOTICE: bisync is EXPERIMENTAL. Don't use in production!
% rclone bisync NFD NFC         
2023/09/02 18:23:17 NOTICE: bisync is EXPERIMENTAL. Don't use in production!
2023/09/02 18:23:17 ERROR : -          Path1 file not found in Path2       - oÃà
2023/09/02 18:23:17 ERROR : -          Path2 file not found in Path1       - √∂
2023/09/02 18:23:17 ERROR : Bisync critical error: path1 and path2 are out of sync, run --resync to recover
2023/09/02 18:23:17 ERROR : Bisync aborted. Must run --resync to recover.
% 
```

As background context: most of the world uses NFC, but macOS prefers NFD for some reason, and will sometimes ([but not always](https://eclecticlight.co/2017/04/06/apfs-is-currently-unusable-with-most-non-english-languages/)) convert NFC filenames to NFD invisibly. (See also: #7072)

Rclone's `copy` and `sync` commands (including the ones used by `bisync` under-the-hood) automatically normalize to NFC, unless `--no-unicode-normalization` is specified. This is why you can usually `rclone sync` between mac and non-mac without issue -- rclone will recognize the NFC and NFD versions as the same filename.

The trouble is that there are three places where bisync does NOT do this:

1. When building the list of files that need to be transferred during `--resync`
2. When building the list of deltas during a non-resync, but only for so-called ["Unusual sync checks"](https://tip.rclone.org/bisync/#unusual-sync-checks)
3. When comparing Path1 to Path2 during `--check-sync`

1 and 2 end up being (mostly) harmless, because although it will try to copy the NFC and NFD versions as different files, the underlying `copy` function it calls is smart enough to realize they are the same file. It will therefore leave the files alone (if already equal) or update one of them (if not equal), but never create a duplicate.

3 is where the problem is most visible. Because `--check-sync` never normalizes, it thinks the NFC and NFD versions are different files. It therefore thinks something went wrong during the bisync run, because at the end of the run the Path1 file list does not exactly match Path2. Accordingly, it throws a critical error. (`--check-sync` is true by default, but can be overridden with `--check-sync=false`.)

The long-term solution is probably that `bisync` should support normalization in the same manner as `sync` (i.e. always normalize when comparing between paths, unless `--no-unicode-normalization` has been specified.) In the mean time, as a short-term solution, the issue can be bypassed by using `--check-sync=false`.

Also worth noting: in https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/5679#issuecomment-1689295692 we are contemplating whether `--check-sync` should perhaps just be replaced by outsourcing it to the more robust [rclone check](https://tip.rclone.org/bisync/#concurrent-modifications), which duplicates a lot of the same functionality, but does it better. That may ultimately be the answer here too, at least for item 3 (`--check-sync`). But I think items 1 and 2 do still need to be addressed regardless, as they are (at best) misleading to users (for instance, dry runs indicate that files will be transferred when they are not in fact new/changed and won't really be transferred.)

One more note: it seems that macOS will accept NFC filenames when created via terminal commands, but not when created via apps or Finder. This is why we don't tend to see these issues at first with files synced from cloud to mac via rclone, but the same files could present issues later if edited by an app or Finder. (This is also why `rclone touch NFC/√∂` in the above repro will work, even on mac.)

<!--- Please keep the note below for others who read your bug report. -->

#### How to use GitHub

* Please use the üëç [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to show that you are affected by the same issue.
* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.

issue.title: bisync: performance

milestone.title: Soon
milestone.description: Issues which are a good idea but haven't been assigned a specific release yet.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
### setup

11,265 files - 290.743MiB (90MB in ~5 files the rest are smaller and more equal in size)

Results the same regardless of Wasabi or iDrive (iDrive typically performs a little faster in every test but only ~5-10% on average)

Remote is using crypt and base32768 encoding. 

BW: ~1.5MiB UP ~5MiB DOWN

### default/common flags

After testing best performing filters are: --transfers 64 --checkers 128 --fast-list

Along with this (--filter-from) or (--filters-file) is also used

e.g. --transfers 64 --checkers 128 --fast-list --filter-from/--filters-file ..

### check

~8s on average and between 6.8s to 9.6s

### ls

(using `time` as no info given with -v)

ls: 0m4.088s
lsl: 7m36.975s

### sync

upload:
	initial: 3m57.0s
	subsequent: 18.6s
	
download:
	initial: 2m9.0s
	subsequent: 17.8s

### copy

upload:
	initial: 4m0.0s
	subsequent 18.6s
	
download:
	initial: 2m6.5s
	subsequent: 16.8s

### bisync

These are some of the best and would say are usually a little longer by upto 5 mins this is likely when resync is run when data is already present vs copying the data itself.. There are no changes made to files when moving between a --resync and normal run.  

defaults:
	resync: 10m47.0s
	normal: 6m44.7s

defaults with ignore checksum: (--ignore-listing-checksum --ignore-checksum)
	resync: 10m36.5s
	normal: 6m31.9s

### overview

So as you can see bisync is orders of magnitude slower than `copy` or `sync` . `ls` is incredibly fast as is `sync` and `copy` in both directions (e.g. uses up almost 100% of bandwidth)

I only ran the test of `lsl` and `ls` at the very end and now thinking that bisync relies on lsl as this so incredibly slow (as I believe bisync does not use checksum so would need `lsl` info to compare?).

I can do a local to crypt (local) bisync in 15s (--resync) and 8.7s for subsequent. 

Is there something I am doing wrong? If not, are there plans/options available to rclone to improve the speed of bisync so that it is more in line with 2 x sync/copy commands (e.g. one upload, one download) or is this a limitation that is unlikely to be overcome? Also, if this is due to lsl taking so long is there a way to speed up lsl? 

Thanks to you all for your hard work and a special thank you @nielash for all you've been doing on bisync and continue to do. I as many others massively appreciate it and when this tool is out of experimental stages it will be a game changer for so many. If I had any free time or money right now I would help out but unfortunately the best I can do is give you some benchmarks and user feedback.

Thanks

issue.title: Bisync should be considered experimental

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### The associated forum post URL from `https://forum.rclone.org`
https://forum.rclone.org/t/bisync-should-be-considered-experimental/29879

#### What is your current rclone version (output from `rclone version`)?
not required

#### What problem are you are trying to solve?
Bisync should be considered experimental and the documentation to reflect that.

#### How do you think rclone should be changed to solve that?
1. https://rclone.org/commands/rclone_bisync/
--- should be labeled `experimental`
--- should have a scary warning, some suggestions are
"Warning, `rclone bisync is advanced command, that is considered experimental. Use at your own risk.
"Can delete files on BOTH the source and dest"
"Can result in the permanent loss of files on the source and dest"
"Important: Since this can cause data loss, test first with the --dry-run or the --interactive/-i flag."

<!--- Please keep the note below for others who read your feature request. -->

* Please use the üëç [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to show that you are affected by the same issue.
* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.
